title: 105_hr2552
content: The "Credit Union Audit Improvement Act of 1997" requires financial statement and audit requirements. The "Credit Union Audit Improvement Act of 1997" mandates that each insured credit union must prepare annual financial statements in accordance with accounting principles and undergo an independent audit by a certified public accountant. Each insured credit union must annually prepare a written assertion on the effectiveness of internal controls over financial reporting. The supervisory committee must obtain an attestation report on the examination of management's assertion, prepared according to accepted standards for attestation. Each insured credit union must annually prepare a written report on compliance with laws and regulations related to safety and soundness. A de minimus exception applies to credit unions with total assets less than $10,000,000. SEC. 3. REQUIREMENTS FOR SUPERVISORY COMMITTEES. Federal Credit Unions: The supervisory committee may, by a unanimous vote, identify risk areas and assess the need for internal and external audit coverage for high-risk activities of the credit union. The supervisory committee of Federal Credit Unions determines high-risk areas and oversees internal and external audits. They must engage independent certified public accountants for outside audits and submit audit reports to the board of directors, Administration, and members. The Federal Credit Union Act requires insured State Credit Unions to maintain a supervisory committee that complies with specific requirements. The amendments made by this Act will be effective for fiscal years ending on or after December 15, 1997.
